issues.title: LAMPs private key representations
issues.author: OR13
issues.body:
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/spasm/KPg3lbPeNms2H5PNDBt0iJByuE0/

We should use the same seeds they use in our test vectors.

comments.author: OR13
comments.body: This is addressed in https://github.com/cose-wg/draft-ietf-cose-dilithium/pull/8

comments.author: ilaril
comments.body:
There is subtle related consideration about the "pub" field in AKP: For some algorithms, it is possible to derive public key from private key, and including both causes possible security issues (e.g., X-Wing bans including public key in private X.509 keys for security reasons). But for others, it is not possible to derive public key from private key, and thus the public key must be present in private keys.

Worst case, inconsistent keys can cause key compromise. Even if Ed25519 and Ed448 are not defined for use with AKP, there is an obvious interpretation for AKP with those algorithms, and for both using inconsistent keys can be instant key compromise (seeing two signatures for the same message with two different public key values exposes the private scalar).

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
Pending a reply to https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/spasm/tI0aW10tiDwrzcg_z8U5kNAmkIw/

I plan to set ctx to the empty string for all algorithms registered in this draft.

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
> The test vectors should document what the various fields are (some appear to be hex, others base64), and maybe the step by step computations. I’m also not sure an all-zero private key, and reusing the same key for all algorithms, is necessarily a good way to generate test vectors. 

We will need to ask the lists regarding this, and potentially coordinate with LAMPS

See: https://github.com/lamps-wg/dilithium-certificates/issues/24

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/gr298YcbmezEnNNA5tfmJ9rnFDE/

I suggest we solve the seed problem first, and then prepare a PR that shows only a change set addressing this issue.

comments.author: panva
comments.body: I find this proposal very un-JOSE like and also a reason to push the document back to a pre-WGLC state.

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body: I agree with Filip.  If the authors are proposing to fundamentally change the key representation, I will request as chair that the document be returned to the working group.  I will also request cross-review by the JOSE working group.

comments.author: ilaril
comments.body: I do not think there is any need for this. AKP works fine with ML-DSA as long as there is no HashML-DSA, and the expert advice is do not use HashML-DSA ("Working Groups SHOULD NOT include HashML-DSA as a signature option." -draft-connolly-cfrg-hybrid-sig-considerations-00).

comments.author: OR13
comments.body: There does not seem to be much support for this, so I am marking it pending close.

pulls.title: WGLC 1 Feedback
pulls.author: OR13
pulls.body:
Attempting to address all feedback in 1 PR.

- https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/LIEk3hcSOUmmttxtKZcLGcLRHUQ/
- https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/QFFTOb5gRi__Muhx374ifk_2upQ/
- https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/Pyja-pj1RYmkdMI2IrUHVRXSmi0/

Pending replies, I plan to add Neil, Russ and Lucas to acknowledgments section

comments.body:
The "pub" and "priv" parameters contain byte strings in format specified by the "alg" value.

E.g., for ML-DSA algorithms, those are presumably ML-DSA public and private (seed) keys (which are byte strings). And for HPKE algorithms, those are presumably HPKE public and private keys for the KEM used by the cipher suite.

And the text should also specify what "pub" (it is the public key) and "priv" (it is the private key, only present for private keys) are.

Then security considerations should talk about mismatched keys, where the public key does not correspond to the private key. Depending on algorithm and implementation, the consequences can range from operations explicitly failing to key compromise.

I added (your) text to address this comment.
Let me know if you would like further changes.

pulls.title: Clarify that pub is required for AKP
pulls.author: OR13

pulls.title: Add priv_exp
pulls.author: OR13
pulls.body:
This PR adds support for priv_exp, as discussed at IETF 122

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/slides-122-cose-ml-dsa-for-jose-and-cose/

comments.author: ilaril
comments.body:
How would this work with hybrid signatures (or native hybrid KEMs)? Those can end up in cases like one of the components being seed-only and the other being expanded-only.

E.g., id-MLDSA65-Ed25519. There is no standard expanded private key format for Ed25519 (I have seen at least two formats that could qualify as "expanded" Ed25519 private keys), while there is for ML-DSA.

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
@ilaril 

> How would this work with hybrid signatures (or native hybrid KEMs)? Those can end up in cases like one of the components being seed-only and the other being expanded-only.
> 
> E.g., id-MLDSA65-Ed25519. There is no standard expanded private key format for Ed25519 (I have seen at least two formats that could qualify as "expanded" Ed25519 private keys), while there is for ML-DSA.

At least for X-Wing, I would imagine:

```
{
   "kid": "T4xl70S7MT...yo0Gu6o",
   "kty": "AKP",
   "alg": "X-Wing",
   "pub": "unH59k4Ru...DZgbTP07e7gEWzw4MFRrndjbDQ",
   "seed/priv": "AAAAAAAAAAA...AAAAAAAAAAAAA", // (not the concatenated expansions)
}
```

Per https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-connolly-cfrg-xwing-kem-06#appendix-C (note that seed and sk are the same).

For the other cases, like chempat - https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-josefsson-chempat-03#section-10

You would have to store `sk_T, sk_PQ`... maybe:

```
{
   "kid": "T4xl70S7MT...yo0Gu6o",
   "kty": "AKP",
   "alg": "Chempat-X25519-mceliece8192128",
   "pub": "unH59k4Ru...DZgbTP07e7gEWzw4MFRrndjbDQ",
   "seed/priv": "...concat(sk_T, sk_PQ, pk_T, pk_PQ)...", // here sk_PQ is expanded I believe, but I could be wrong
}
```

The point would be that in order to use an AKP key, you would need to understand how to process all the mandatory key parameters for a given algorithm.

Some algorithms might be as simple as "priv", others might look like RSA does today... 

I think we have learned that opaque byte string parameters are best, and so as much as possible, we should aim for the minimum number of opaque byte strings needed to support interop.

If you want "unbounded algorithmic agility (feature or bug, depending on your view of history)", where the same key is used with a potentially unbounded number of algorithms, you can easily do that with AKP, you just have to say which specific algorithm you are trying to support, and the fingerprint will commit to that algorithm.

comments.author: ilaril
comments.body:
> > How would this work with hybrid signatures (or native hybrid KEMs)? Those can end up in cases like one of the components being seed-only and the other being expanded-only.
> 
> At least for X-Wing, I would imagine:

Yes, X-Wing is easy as it always uses "super-seed" (which is internally used to generate seeds for both components).
 
> For the other cases, like chempat - https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-josefsson-chempat-03#section-10
> 
> You would have to store `sk_T, sk_PQ`... maybe:

There are 9 possible combinations of seeds and expanded keys there.

E.g., how does one store `sk_T` being seed-only, while `sk_PQ` is expanded-only?


> The point would be that in order to use an AKP key, you would need to understand how to process all the mandatory key parameters for a given algorithm.
>
> Some algorithms might be as simple as "priv", others might look like RSA does today...
> 
> I think we have learned that opaque byte string parameters are best, and so as much as possible, we should aim for the minimum number of opaque byte strings needed to support interop.

Because processing of the private key octet string can be algorithm-dependent, the minimum number of private parameters is 1.
That is, one can always do with just "priv", "priv_exp" is never needed.

E.g., with primitive algorithms, one can prepend a flag byte (01 => Seed, 02 => Expanded, 03 => Both). With composite algorithms, one can, e.g., do it like draft-ietf-lamps-pq-composite-sigs-04.

Ideally, the COSE/JOSE code would just stuff the raw private/public key to some library that then transparently handles the internals.

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
The current proposal in this draft is closed to this:

> E.g., with primitive algorithms, one can prepend a flag byte (01 => Seed, 02 => Expanded, 03 => Both). 

Its just we use CBOR / JSON to handle the prepending, and the both case, is handled by the presence of 2 map keys.

@ilaril would you mind giving a thumbs up / thumbs down to any of the suggested changes on this PR?

comments.author: ilaril
comments.body:
I think this would be tolerable if the section "Algorithm Key Pair Type" made it clear what to do with algorithms that do not have defined seed expansion, and that the matching requirement is independent of algorithm.

For example, COSE-HPKE and JOSE-HPKE algorithms do not have seed expansion (even if using X-Wing as KEM!). Also, any hybrid signature algorithms are unlikely to have any defined seed expansion.


Maybe something like (with fields renamed):

_If the associated "alg" value does not define seed expansion, then "seed" parameter MUST NOT be present, and the "priv" parameter is used for the private key, if present._

_If both "seed" and "priv" parameters are both present, then the seed in "seed" parameter MUST expand to the key in "priv" parameter following the seed expansion procedure for the associated "alg" value._

comments.author: OR13
comments.body: @ilaril I agree, I will make it clear that the parameters for a given AKP come from the algorithm.

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
@ilaril I ended up applying both suggestions, based on @selfissued 's comment.

I'm going to push a draft version to the list, to enable better review.

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
The key parameters for public and private information classes contain byte strings in a format specified by the "alg" value.
```

```suggestion
When registering new algorithms, use of multiple key parameters for private information is NOT RECOMMENDED.
```

```suggestion
When AKP keys are expressed in JWK, key parameters are base64url encoded.
```

```suggestion
When both "priv" and "priv_exp" are present, the "priv" parameter MUST expand to the "priv_exp" parameter.
See Security Considerations of this document for details.
```

```suggestion
### ML-DSA Private Key
```

```suggestion
#### AKP Private Key
```

reviews.author: selfissued
reviews.body:
Simo Sorce's [suggestion on the list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/jose/9u6XQ9cff_smC0PosebgIO3o5CU/) resonates with me:
> If priv is the seed, why not call it just 'seed' ?

I suggest adding a "seed" ML-DSA-specific JWK parameter and using "priv" for the expanded form.

Likewise, I suggest a parallel change for COSE where "seed" is given the -3 label instead of "priv_exp" and "priv" with label -2 is used for the expanded private key.

(Note:  I am writing this as an individual - not a COSE chair.)

comments.body:
```suggestion
1. Only the "seed" parameter is present.
```

```suggestion
2. Only the "priv" parameter is present.
```

```suggestion
For ML-DSA keys, when "seed" is present, it MUST have a length of 32 bytes.
```

```suggestion
When both "seed" and "priv" are present, the "seed" parameter MUST expand to the "priv" parameter.
```

```suggestion
Here is an elided example of the case where both "seed" and "priv" are present:
```

```suggestion
   "seed": "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA",
```

```suggestion
   "priv": "129kadu...DZgbTP07e7gEWzw4MFRr54"
```

```suggestion
Note that "seed" size is always 32 bytes, and that KeyGen_internal is called to produce the private key sizes for "priv" in the table above.
```

```suggestion
However, if the private key ("priv") is derived from the seed using KeyGen_internal is stored as part of some implementation, the skEncode and skDecode algorithms MUST be used.
```

```suggestion
### ML-DSA Private Key Seed

* Key Type: TBD (requested assignment 7)
* Name: seed
* Label: -3
* CBOR Type: bstr
* Description: Private key seed
```

```suggestion
#### AKP Private Key Seed

* Parameter Name: seed
* Parameter Description: Private key seed
```

```suggestion
3. Both parameters are present.

For ML-DSA keys, when "priv" is present, "seed" SHOULD be present to enable validation of the private key expansion process. 
Validation and expansion of private keys might be skipped in constrained environments.
```

cc @simo5 per discussion on the list.

This would assume we apply the suggestions to rename "priv" -> "seed" and "priv_exp" -> "priv".

This does not seem to say what to do with algorithms without defined seed expansion, or that seed and private key are supposed to match if both are present (AKP is supposed to be much more generic than just ML-DSA). Copying earlier suggested text as suggested change:

```suggestion

If the associated "alg" value does not define seed expansion, then "seed" parameter MUST NOT be present, and the "priv" parameter is used for the private key, if present.

If both "seed" and "priv" parameters are present, then the seed in "seed" parameter MUST expand to the key in "priv" parameter following the seed expansion procedure for the associated "alg" value.
```

```suggestion
The "seed" parameter contains private information and MUST NOT be present in public keys.

Whether "seed" is allowed, and how it is related to "pub" and "priv" is algorithm specific and needs to be described as part of specifying the use of AKP for a given algorithm, see below for an example of how this is done for ML-DSA.
```

> AKP is supposed to be much more generic than just ML-DSA

This was the original reason why I left the discussion of seeds to the alg specific key section.

I was not sure I could craft generic text that would work for all future "alg" values.

I would prefer to leave this level of detail to the following section that is alg specific.

Perhaps instead we might say something like:

https://github.com/cose-wg/draft-ietf-cose-dilithium/pull/16/files#r2023090886

reviews.author: selfissued
reviews.body:
I agree that this is now the right way to make this change, after the recent suggestions have been incorporated.

I do have questions (as an individual) whether this change is needed at all.  But we should discuss that on the list.
